meta.dc:subject: legislation
meta.dc:rights: The Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

main.longTitle: An Ordinance to provide for a mechanism for fire safety improvements to be made to certain industrial buildings and for related matters; to rectify a textual error in the application section of the Fire Safety (Commercial Premises) Ordinance; and to amend specified exceptions to the offences of disclosing information obtained officially under that Ordinance and under the Fire Safety (Buildings) Ordinance.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title
section.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Fire Safety (Industrial Buildings) Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation
section.def: authorized officer (獲授權人員) means—(a)the Director of Fire Services;(b)the Director of Buildings;(c)a police officer; or(d)a public officer appointed under section 33;
certificate of compliance (符合安全證明書) means a certificate of compliance issued under section 27;

enforcement authority (執行當局) means—(a)in relation to any fire service installation or equipment—the Director of Fire Services; or(b)in relation to the planning, design and construction of a building—the Director of Buildings;
fire safety compliance order (符合消防安全令) means a fire safety compliance order made under section 13, and includes a fire safety compliance order varied under section 14;
fire safety direction (消防安全指示) means a fire safety direction issued under section 5, 6 or 7, and includes a fire safety direction amended under section 9;

fire safety requirement (消防安全規定) means—(a)in relation to an owner of a building or a part of a building—all or any of the requirements in Schedule 1; or(b)in relation to an occupier of a building or a part of a building—all or any of the requirements in Schedule 2;

fire service installation or equipment (消防裝置或設備) means any installation or equipment manufactured, used or designed to be used for—(a)extinguishing, attacking, preventing or limiting a fire;(b)giving warning of a fire;(c)providing access to any premises or place for extinguishing, attacking, preventing or limiting a fire;(d)facilitating evacuation from any premises or place in case of fire; or(e)providing a stand-by power supply to an installation or equipment that is for any purpose mentioned in paragraph (a), (b), (c) or (d) in the event of the loss of normal power supply;
function (職能) includes a power and a duty;
mechanical ventilating system (機械通風系統) includes an air conditioning system;
occupier (佔用人) means a person who is occupying a building or a part of a building, whether as an owner or under any form of lease or licence;
owner (擁有人) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Buildings Ordinance (Cap. 123);
owners’ corporation (業主立案法團) means a corporation registered under section 8 of the Building Management Ordinance (Cap. 344);
prohibition order (禁止令) means a prohibition order made under section 18.

subsection.content: This Ordinance applies to the whole of a building that is an industrial building.

subsection.leadIn: For subsection (1), a building is an industrial building only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all or part of the building was constructed for use as a factory, industrial undertaking, godown, warehouse, place of bulk storage, or similar industrial premises; and

subparagraph.content: the building or the part was constructed in accordance with building plans that had first been submitted to the Building Authority for approval on or before 1 March 1987, and that were approved under the Buildings Ordinance (Cap. 123); or

the building or the part was constructed on or before 1 March 1987, and no building plans for it had been submitted to the Building Authority for approval under the Buildings Ordinance (Cap. 123) on or before that date.

subsection.content: However, this Ordinance does not apply to a building if the Fire Safety (Commercial Premises) Ordinance (Cap. 502) or the Fire Safety (Buildings) Ordinance (Cap. 572) applies to the whole of the building.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: industrial undertaking (工業經營) includes any premises on which articles are manufactured, altered, cleansed, repaired, ornamented, finished, adapted for sale, broken up or demolished, or on which materials are transformed.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Unoccupied building regarded as occupied by owner
section.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, if a building or a part of a building is unoccupied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: its owner is regarded as its occupier;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an enforcement authority may exercise any of its powers under this Ordinance in relation to an occupier for the building or part by exercising them in relation to the owner for that building or part; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the owner’s liability arising from an enforcement authority’s exercise of powers under paragraph (b) is unaffected by the building or part being subsequently occupied.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Directing owner to comply with fire safety requirement

subsection.content: If a building has only 1 owner, an enforcement authority may issue and serve on the owner a fire safety direction to direct the owner to comply with a fire safety requirement for the building.

subsection.leadIn: If a building has more than one owner and each owner has the right to exclusively occupy a part of it, an enforcement authority may issue and serve on any of the owners a fire safety direction to direct the owner to comply with a fire safety requirement for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the part of the building that the owner has the right to exclusively occupy; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a part of the building that none of the owners has the right to exclusively occupy.

subsection.content: If different owners of a building have the right to exclusively occupy different parts of the building, then in order to integrate fire service installations or equipment among those parts, a fire safety direction may include a direction to any of the owners to provide the relevant connections, or other forms of integration, for the installations or equipment.

subsection.leadIn: Moreover, in order to integrate fire service installations or equipment between—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a part of a building that an owner of the building has the right to exclusively occupy; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a part of the building that none of the owners of the building has the right to exclusively occupy,

subsection.continued: a fire safety direction may include a direction to the owners concerned to provide the relevant connections, or other forms of integration, for the installations or equipment.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Directing occupier to comply with fire safety requirement
section.content: An enforcement authority may issue and serve on the occupier of a building or a part of a building a fire safety direction to direct the occupier to comply with a fire safety requirement for the building or part.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Directing other appropriate measures
section.leadIn: If an enforcement authority considers that it would be unreasonable to direct the owner or occupier of a building or a part of a building to comply with a fire safety requirement having regard to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the structural integrity of the building or part;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the technology available to comply with the requirement; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other relevant factors,

section.continued: the authority may issue and serve on the owner or occupier a fire safety direction to direct the owner or occupier to take other measures the authority considers appropriate instead of complying with the requirement.

subsection.content: A fire safety direction must be in writing.
A fire safety direction must specify the time limit for compliance with it.
The time limit must allow reasonable time for compliance.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Amending or withdrawing fire safety direction
section.content: An enforcement authority that has issued a fire safety direction may from time to time amend or withdraw it by written notice.

section.name: s10
section.heading: When fire safety direction ceases to be in force
section.leadIn: A fire safety direction for a building or a part of a building ceases to be in force if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a certificate of compliance is issued for the building or part;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the enforcement authority withdraws the direction under section 9; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the direction is replaced by a fire safety compliance order.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Not complying with fire safety direction is offence

subsection.content: An owner or occupier of a building or a part of a building who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a fire safety direction for the building or part commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to a fine at level 4; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to a further fine of $2,500 for each day (or part of a day) during which the failure continues after the expiry of the time limit for complying with the fire safety direction.

subsection.leadIn: The reasonable excuse referred to in subsection (1) includes, but is not limited to, it not being reasonable to expect the owner or occupier to comply with the direction during the time for complying with it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: because compliance would pose a risk of prejudicially affecting the structural integrity of the building or part; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: because the technology required for compliance is not reasonably available.

subsection.leadIn: An enforcement authority may set up an advisory committee to advise the authority on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether to direct the owner or occupier of a building or a part of a building to take other appropriate measures under section 7; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if so—what measures would be appropriate.

subsection.content: Members of an advisory committee must be persons with relevant expertise whom the enforcement authority considers appropriate.
Only the enforcement authority may refer a case to an advisory committee for advice.
An advisory committee may by written notice invite representations from the owner or occupier, and consider them before advising on a case.
If an advisory committee has advised on a case, the enforcement authority must consider the advice.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Magistrate may make fire safety compliance order

subsection.content: A magistrate who finds an owner or occupier guilty of an offence under section 11(1) for failing to comply with a fire safety direction may, on the application of the enforcement authority, make a fire safety compliance order to order the owner or occupier to comply with any requirement or measure specified in the direction.
The owner or occupier is entitled to be heard at the hearing of the application.
A fire safety compliance order must specify the time limit for compliance with it.
The time limit must allow reasonable time for compliance.
A fire safety compliance order replaces the fire safety direction.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Varying or revoking fire safety compliance order

subsection.content: If a magistrate makes a fire safety compliance order against an owner or occupier, the magistrate may vary or make an order revoking the fire safety compliance order on the application of the enforcement authority or the owner or occupier.
The enforcement authority and the owner or occupier are entitled to be heard at the hearing of the application.

section.name: s15
section.heading: When fire safety compliance order ceases to be in force

subsection.leadIn: A fire safety compliance order for a building or a part of a building ceases to be in force if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a certificate of compliance is issued for the building or part; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the magistrate revokes the order under section 14.

subsection.leadIn: If subsection (1)(a) applies, the enforcement authority must as soon as practicable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give written notification to the magistrate’s clerk that a certificate of compliance has been issued; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: serve on the owner or occupier a copy of the notification.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Not complying with fire safety compliance order is offence

subsection.content: An owner or occupier of a building or a part of a building who fails to comply with a fire safety compliance order for the building or part commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to a fine at level 5; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to a further fine of $5,000 for each day (or part of a day) during which the failure continues after the expiry of the time limit for complying with the fire safety compliance order.

subsection.content: An enforcement authority may apply to the District Court for a prohibition order for a building or a part of a building if the authority considers that a requirement or measure specified in a fire safety direction, or in a fire safety compliance order, for the building or part has not been complied with by an owner or occupier of the building or part.
An application may only be made after the expiry of the time limit for complying with the fire safety direction or the fire safety compliance order.
An enforcement authority must give at least 7 days’ notice to the owner or occupier before making the application.

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after giving notice under subsection (3), the enforcement authority must post a copy of the notice at a conspicuous place—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: inside the building or part; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at, or in the immediate vicinity of, each entrance to the building or part.

section.name: s18
section.heading: District Court may make prohibition order

subsection.content: An application under section 17 is to be heard and determined in accordance with the rules of court made under section 72 of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336).

subsection.leadIn: At the hearing of an application under section 17, the District Court may make an order for a building or a part of a building prohibiting the occupation of the building or part if satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the owner or occupier of the building or part has failed to comply with a requirement or measure specified in a fire safety direction or in a fire safety compliance order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is reasonable to expect the owner or occupier to comply with the requirement or measure;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the time allowed for complying with the requirement or measure is reasonable;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: it is reasonable and necessary in the circumstances to make the order; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: there are substantial fire risks if the building or part is occupied.

subsection.leadIn: While a prohibition order is in force for a building or a part of a building, no person may occupy the building or part, except—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person with a permission granted under subsection (2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an authorized officer acting in the course of duty.

subsection.content: If an enforcement authority considers appropriate, it may, subject to suitable conditions, by written notice permit a person to occupy the building or part for implementing measures necessary for the discharge or revocation of the prohibition order.
The enforcement authority may cancel the permission granted under subsection (2) at any time.

While a prohibition order is in force for a building or a part of a building, the owner and occupier of the building or part must take all practicable measures to ensure the building or part is effectively secured against entry by any person other than a person referred to in subsection (1)(a) or (b).

If a prohibition order is in force for a building or a part of a building, the enforcement authority must, as soon as practicable after issuing a certificate of compliance for the building or part, apply to the District Court for discharge of the order.
The application must be accompanied by a copy of the certificate of compliance.
The District Court must on the application make an order to discharge the prohibition order, unless it considers that there are special grounds for not doing so.

subsection.leadIn: If a prohibition order is in force for a building or a part of a building and the enforcement authority—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: rejects a request for a certificate of compliance made under section 26(1) for the building or part by the owner or occupier concerned; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to issue a certificate of compliance for the building or part within 28 days after the date on which the owner or occupier concerned gives a notice under the section requesting the certificate,

subsection.continued: the owner or occupier may apply to the District Court for an order to revoke the prohibition order.

subsection.content: The applicant must, within 7 days after making the application, give written notice of the application by delivering it personally or sending it by post to the enforcement authority.
The enforcement authority is entitled to be heard at the hearing of the application.
At the hearing of the application, the court may make any order it considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: A prohibition order for a building or a part of a building comes into force—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the owner or occupier concerned does not appeal against the order—on the 29th day after the date of service of a copy of the order on the owner and occupier; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the owner or occupier appeals against the order (including an appeal against a decision determining the appeal)—on the day following the date on which the appeal is finally rejected or is withdrawn.

subsection.leadIn: However, the District Court may, if it considers appropriate in a particular case, order that a prohibition order comes into force—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the date of service of a copy of the prohibition order on the owner and occupier concerned; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on a date within 28 days after the date of service.

subsection.leadIn: For subsections (1) and (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: service must be in a way other than by posting in accordance with section 24(1)(a); and

subparagraph.content: if copies are served on the owner and occupier on the same date—that date; or
if copies are served on the owner and occupier on different dates—the last of those dates.

subsection.leadIn: A prohibition order ceases to be in force on the earliest of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the discharge of the order under section 20;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the revocation of the order under section 21; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the building or part ceasing to exist.

subsection.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, contravenes section 19(1) commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to a fine of $250,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to a further fine of $25,000 for each day (or part of a day) during which the contravention continues.

subsection.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, contravenes section 19(4) commits an offence.
A person who commits an offence under subsection (3) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Posting and service of copy of prohibition order

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after the District Court makes a prohibition order for a building or a part of a building, the enforcement authority must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: post a copy of the order at a conspicuous place—

subparagraph.content: inside the building or part; or
at, or in the immediate vicinity of, each entrance to the building or part; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: serve, in a way other than by posting in accordance with paragraph (a), a copy of the order on the owner and occupier concerned.

subsection.content: If a prohibition order is in force and a copy of the order is posted under subsection (1)(a), a person who, without lawful authority, removes, defaces or in another way interferes with the copy commits an offence.
A person who commits an offence under subsection (2) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 2.
The enforcement authority must, as soon as practicable after a prohibition order ceases to be in force, remove all copies of the order posted under subsection (1)(a).

section.name: s25
section.heading: Power to remove persons from building
section.leadIn: While a prohibition order is in force for a building or a part of a building, a police officer of or above the rank of inspector may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: remove from the building or part any person who is apparently contravening, or about to contravene, section 19(1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prevent the person from re-entering the building or part while the order is in force.

subsection.content: While a fire safety direction or fire safety compliance order is in force for a building or a part of a building, the owner or occupier concerned may, by written notice given by delivering it personally or sending it by post to the enforcement authority, request the authority to issue a certificate of compliance for the building or part.
A certificate of compliance must certify that the requirements or measures specified in a fire safety direction or in a fire safety compliance order have been complied with.

If the enforcement authority is satisfied that the requirements or measures specified in a fire safety direction or in a fire safety compliance order have been complied with, the authority must as soon as practicable issue a certificate of compliance to the owner or occupier concerned.

subsection.leadIn: The function under subsection (1) may be performed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at the request of the owner or occupier concerned made under section 26(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on the enforcement authority’s own initiative.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Rejecting request for certificate of compliance
section.content: If the enforcement authority rejects the request of the owner or occupier made under section 26(1), the authority must as soon as practicable by written notice inform the owner or occupier of the rejection and the reasons for it.

division.name: D5
division.heading: Registering Certain Instruments in Land Registry

section.name: s29
section.heading: Orders may be registered in Land Registry
section.leadIn: An enforcement authority may cause to be registered by memorial in the Land Registry against the land register of a building or a part of a building—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a fire safety compliance order for the building or part; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a prohibition order for the building or part.

subsection.leadIn: If a fire safety compliance order is registered under section 29 for a building or a part of a building, the enforcement authority must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the order is subsequently varied or revoked under section 14(1)—cause the varied fire safety compliance order or the revocation order to be registered for the building or part; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a certificate of compliance is subsequently issued for the building or part—cause the certificate to be registered for the building or part.

subsection.leadIn: If a prohibition order is registered under section 29 for a building or a part of a building, the enforcement authority must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the order is subsequently discharged under section 20(3)—cause the discharge order to be registered for the building or part; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if an order is subsequently made under section 21(4)—cause the subsequent order to be registered for the building or part.

subsection.content: If an enforcement authority is required to cause an instrument to be registered under this section, the authority must, as soon as practicable within 1 month beginning on the date of the instrument, cause it to be registered by memorial in the Land Registry against the land register of the building or part.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Registration in relation to owners’ corporation

subsection.content: This section applies for the purposes of registration under sections 29 and 30 only.

If an order referred to in section 29(a) or 30(1)(a) is made for a building or a part of a building against an owners’ corporation, the order is regarded as having been made against each owner of the building or part individually.

If a certificate referred to in section 30(1)(b) is issued for a building or a part of a building to an owners’ corporation, the certificate is regarded as having been issued to each owner of the building or part individually.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Publishing information
section.leadIn: In order to provide appropriate information to the public, an enforcement authority may upload onto its departmental website, or in another way publish, information about a fire safety direction, a fire safety compliance order, or a prohibition order, for a building or a part of a building, including but not limited to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the serial number of the direction or order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the address of the building or part;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the date of the direction or order; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the compliance status of the direction or order.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Appointment of authorized officers
section.content: An enforcement authority may appoint a public officer in writing to be an authorized officer for the purposes of this Ordinance.

section.name: s34
section.heading: Assistant to authorized officer
section.content: When performing a function under this Ordinance, an authorized officer may be assisted by the persons who are reasonably required for performing the function.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Production of identification documents required when performing function
section.leadIn: When performing a function under this Ordinance, an authorized officer must, if asked, produce for inspection identification documents that show his or her identity as an authorized officer, such as—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an identification document of the post held; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a copy of any appointment under section 33.

division.name: D2
division.heading: Power to Enter Building and Other Powers

section.name: s36
section.heading: Power to enter building without warrant

subsection.content: If an authorized officer knows or reasonably believes that a building is one to which this Ordinance applies, the officer may enter and inspect the building or a part of the building during any reasonable hours without warrant in order to perform a function under this Ordinance.

If an authorized officer knows or reasonably believes that an offence under this Ordinance is being or has been committed in a building or a part of a building, the officer may also enter and inspect the building or part during any reasonable hours without warrant.

subsection.leadIn: On application by an enforcement authority, a magistrate may issue a warrant for a building or a part of a building if it is shown to the magistrate’s satisfaction on sworn or affirmed information that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the building is one to which this Ordinance applies or there is a good reason for an authorized officer to believe so;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: one of the following cases applies—

subparagraph.content: the building or part is unoccupied;
an authorized officer, after making reasonable efforts, has not been able to contact the owner or occupier of the building or part;
admission to the building or part has been refused, or refusal of admission is reasonably expected;
the owner or occupier of the building or part is unreasonably delaying admission to the building or part;
the case is one of urgency; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: there is a good reason for an authorized officer to enter the building or part.

subsection.content: A warrant may authorize an authorized officer to enter the building or part, if necessary by force.
A warrant must state the purpose of entry.

section.name: s38
section.heading: When warrant ceases to be in force
section.leadIn: A warrant issued under section 37(1) ceases to be in force on the earlier of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the end of 1 month beginning on the date of issue; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the fulfilment of the purpose stated in the warrant.

section.name: s39
section.heading: Security to be maintained after entering unoccupied building with warrant
section.content: If an authorized officer enters an unoccupied building or an unoccupied part of a building pursuant to a warrant issued under section 37(1), the officer must ensure that, on leaving the building or part, it is as effectively secured against trespassers as it was immediately before the entry.

section.name: s40
section.heading: Power to require information
section.leadIn: An authorized officer may require a person to provide information that may identify an owner or occupier of a building or a part of a building, but only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the officer reasonably believes that the person has the information; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the information cannot readily be obtained by inspecting a public record.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refuses or fails to answer a question put to the person under section 40; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provides an answer that the person knows or ought reasonably to know is false or misleading.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4.
A person who, without lawful authority, discloses to another person information obtained while performing a function under this Ordinance commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: For subsection (1), the person has lawful authority if the person discloses the information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in order to perform a function under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in connection with proceedings brought under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in relation to performing a function, or for enabling or facilitating any thing or work to be done by any person, under any law of Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in compliance with a court order; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: with the consent of each person who is entitled to have the information kept confidential.

subsection.content: For subsection (2)(e), information that a person is entitled to have kept confidential includes, but is not limited to, information that concerns the trade, business or profession of the person or another person with whom the person has business dealings.
A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.
A person who, without reasonable excuse, resists, obstructs or delays an authorized officer who is performing, or is attempting to perform, a function under this Ordinance commits an offence.
A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s44
section.heading: Government not liable for failure to perform function
section.content: The Government, an enforcement authority or an authorized officer does not incur liability for damages only because of a failure to perform a function under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: An authorized officer is not civilly liable for an act done or omitted to be done by the officer in good faith in performing or purportedly performing a function under this Ordinance.
Subsection (1) does not affect any liability of the Government for the act or omission.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Offences by body corporate and partnership

subsection.leadIn: If an offence under this Ordinance is committed by a body corporate (other than an owners’ corporation) and it is proved that the offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was committed with the consent or connivance of a director of the body corporate or other person concerned in the management of the body corporate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was attributable to any neglect or omission on the part of the director or the other person,

subsection.continued: the director or the other person also commits the offence.

subsection.leadIn: If an offence under this Ordinance is committed by an owners’ corporation and it is proved that the offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was committed with the consent or connivance of a person concerned in the management of the corporation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was attributable to any neglect or omission on the part of the person,

subsection.continued: the person also commits the offence.

subsection.leadIn: If an offence under this Ordinance is committed by a partner of a partnership and it is proved that the offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was committed with the consent or connivance of any other partner concerned in the management of the partnership; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was attributable to any neglect or omission on the part of the other partner,

subsection.continued: the other partner also commits the offence.

section.name: s47
section.heading: Prosecution deadline
section.content: A prosecution for an offence under this Ordinance may only be started before the end of 12 months beginning on the date on which the offence is discovered by, or comes to the notice of, the enforcement authority.

paragraph.content: This replaces the time limit under section 26 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227).

section.name: s48
section.heading: Service on non-body corporate
section.leadIn: If a document for a building or a part of a building is to be given to or served on a person under this Ordinance by an enforcement authority and the person is not a body corporate, the document may be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: delivered personally to the person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: sent by registered post to the person’s usual address of residence or business, or (if that address is unknown) to the person’s last known address of residence or business;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: left with an adult occupier of the building or part;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: posted at a conspicuous place inside the building or part;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: sent by facsimile transmission to the facsimile number of the person, or (if that number is unknown) to the person’s last known facsimile number; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: sent by electronic mail to the electronic mail address of the person, or (if that address is unknown) to the person’s last known electronic mail address.

subsection.leadIn: If a document for a building or a part of a building is to be given to or served on a person under this Ordinance by an enforcement authority and the person is a body corporate (other than a registered non-Hong Kong company), the document may be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: delivered personally to any address in Hong Kong at which the body corporate carries on business, and given to a person apparently concerned in the management of, or employed by, the body corporate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: sent by registered post to the registered office in Hong Kong of the body corporate, or to any address in Hong Kong at which the body corporate carries on business, or (if that address is unknown) to the last known registered or business address of the body corporate;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: left with an adult occupier of the building or part;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: posted at a conspicuous place inside the building or part;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: sent by facsimile transmission to the facsimile number of the body corporate, or (if that number is unknown) to the last known facsimile number of the body corporate; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: sent by electronic mail to the electronic mail address of the body corporate, or (if that address is unknown) to the last known electronic mail address of the body corporate.

subsection.leadIn: If a document for a building or a part of a building is to be given to or served on a person under this Ordinance by an enforcement authority and the person is a registered non-Hong Kong company, the document may be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: delivered personally to the address of the authorized representative as shown in the Companies Register, and given to the authorized representative;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: sent by registered post to the authorized representative at that address;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: left with an adult occupier of the building or part;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: posted at a conspicuous place inside the building or part;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: sent by facsimile transmission to the facsimile number of the authorized representative, or (if that number is unknown) to the last known facsimile number of the representative; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: sent by electronic mail to the electronic mail address of the authorized representative, or (if that address is unknown) to the last known electronic mail address of the representative.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: authorized representative (獲授權代表) means an authorized representative as defined by section 774(1) of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622);
Companies Register (公司登記冊) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622);
registered non-Hong Kong company (註冊非香港公司) means a registered non-Hong Kong company as defined by section 2(1) of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622).

section.name: s50
section.heading: Date of giving or service of documents
section.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, a document given or served is taken, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to have been given or served—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if delivered personally, left with a person or posted at a place—on the day after the day on which it was delivered, left or posted;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if sent by post—on the second working day after the day on which it was posted;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if sent by facsimile transmission—on the day after the day on which it was sent; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if sent by electronic mail—on the day after the day on which it was sent.

section.name: s51
section.heading: Certificate of giving or service admissible as evidence

subsection.content: A certificate purporting to be signed by, or for, an enforcement authority stating that a document has been given or served is admissible in evidence in any proceedings brought under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Unless there is evidence to the contrary, it is presumed that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the certificate is signed by, or for, the enforcement authority; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the document to which the certificate relates was duly given or served.

subsection.content: An enforcement authority or a public officer appointed under section 33 may certify a copy or print of (or an extract from) a document made, issued, given or served for the purposes of this Ordinance as a true copy or print of (or extract from) the document.

subsection.leadIn: The document referred to in subsection (1) includes, but is not limited to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a fire safety direction;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a notice amending or withdrawing a fire safety direction under section 9;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a fire safety compliance order;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a prohibition order;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a certificate of compliance;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: building plans showing that a building is one to which this Ordinance applies; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: correspondence by the enforcement authority with an owner or occupier of a building or a part of a building in connection with this Ordinance.

section.name: s53
section.heading: Certified true copy admissible as evidence

subsection.leadIn: A copy or print of (or an extract from) a document is admissible in evidence in proceedings before any court on its production without further proof if the copy, print or extract—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: purports to be a true copy or print of (or extract from) the document; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has been certified under section 52.

subsection.leadIn: The court before which the certified true copy, print or extract is produced must, unless there is evidence to the contrary, presume that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the certification is by an enforcement authority or a public officer appointed under section 33; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is a true copy, print or extract.

section.name: s54
section.heading: Power to make regulations
section.content: The Secretary for Security may make regulations for the better carrying into effect of the provisions and purposes of this Ordinance.

section.name: s55
section.heading: Substituted or amended codes of practice

subsection.content: The Secretary for Security may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend Schedule 1 or 2 by substituting or amending the references to any code of practice in the Schedule.
A notice under subsection (1) is subject to the approval of the Legislative Council.
A notice under subsection (1) must not take effect on a day before the date on which the notice is published in the Gazette.

schedule.name: sch1
schedule.heading: Requirements to be Complied with by Owners

section.name: s1
section.heading: Provision of fire service installations or equipment

subsection.leadIn: In relation to the provision of fire service installations or equipment, an enforcement authority may direct an owner of a building or a part of a building to comply with the following requirements—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to provide or improve an automatic sprinkler system, with or without a direct link to the system of the Fire Services Department, to control the spread of fire and to sound an alarm;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to provide or improve a fire hydrant and hose reel system as a source of water supply for firefighting;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to provide or improve a manual fire alarm system to alert persons in the building in the event of fire;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to provide or improve emergency lighting within the common areas of the building to facilitate the evacuation of persons in the building in the event of a power failure;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to provide or improve exit signs (including directional signs) indicating an exit route to facilitate the evacuation of persons in the building in the event of fire;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to provide or improve a secondary source of electrical power supply (whether in the form of an emergency generator or otherwise) to provide a stand-by power supply to fire service installations or equipment or a fireman’s lift in the event of the loss of normal power supply;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: if a mechanical ventilating system is provided in the building or part and the system forms an integral part of the building or part—to provide or improve an automatic cut-off device for the system to limit the spread of smoke through the system; and

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: to provide or improve other fire service installations or equipment in accordance with the requirements specified in the Code of Practice for Minimum Fire Service Installations and Equipment 2012 published by the Director of Fire Services (2012 Code).

subsection.content: The detailed specifications and requirements of the installations or equipment under subsection (1)(a), (b), (c), (d), (e), (f) and (g) are set out in the 2012 Code.

subsection.leadIn: In relation to the design, construction or installation of fire safety construction, an enforcement authority may direct an owner of a building or a part of a building to comply with the following requirements—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to means of escape—to improve the exit arrangements on storeys and at ground storeys;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to means of access for firefighting and rescue—to provide fireman’s lifts; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to fire resisting construction—

subparagraph.content: to protect exit routes and staircases with separating walls of fire resisting construction;
to improve the fire resistance of external walls, and to protect openings in the external walls to inhibit the spread of fire to adjoining buildings;
to provide fire resisting separation between different parts of the building; and
to provide smoke vents to basements.

subsection.content: The detailed specifications and requirements of the fire safety construction under subsection (1) are set out in the Code of Practice for Fire Safety in Buildings 2011 (October 2015 version) published by the Buildings Department.

schedule.name: sch2
schedule.heading: Requirements to be Complied with by Occupiers

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation
section.def: fire compartment (防火間), in relation to a building, means a space enclosed at all sides by fire barriers (or appropriate construction) that meet the standards of fire resistance rating prescribed by the Code of Practice for Fire Safety in Buildings 2011 (October 2015 version) published by the Buildings Department.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Provision of fire service installations or equipment

subsection.leadIn: In relation to the provision of fire service installations or equipment, an enforcement authority may direct an occupier of a building or a part of a building to comply with the following requirements—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to provide or improve emergency lighting within the area occupied by the occupier (occupied area) to facilitate the evacuation of persons in the area in the event of a power failure; and

paragraph.name: b

subparagraph.content: a mechanical ventilating system is provided in the occupied area and the system serves only the occupied area; and

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: has a capacity to process air at a rate exceeding 1 cubic metre per second; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: serves more than one fire compartment located within the occupied area,

paragraph.continued: to provide or improve an automatic cut-off device for the system to limit the spread of smoke through the system.

subsection.content: The detailed specifications and requirements of the installations or equipment under subsection (1) are set out in the Code of Practice for Minimum Fire Service Installations and Equipment 2012 published by the Director of Fire Services.
